info.title: Gathering System Information for Support
info.meta: Use supportconfig to pass information to SUSE support
How to use the supportconfig tool to pass information to the SUSE support

listitem.para: The article gives instructions on how to gather information that can be passed to the SUSE support.
You want to know how to properly gather information about your system if there is a problem with the system.
It takes up to 15 minutes of reading time.
You will learn how to create an archive of information about your system that can provide details about problems in your system to the SUSE support.

info.title: Why collect system information and logs?

abstract.para: The supportconfig command-line tool collects and organizes detailed system information and logs in a way that helps to reduce service request resolution times.

section.para: Private system information can be disclosed during the process of collecting information from the tool. If this is a concern, you can remove the private data from the log files. There are other options to exclude more sensitive data. supportconfig data is used only for diagnostic purposes and is confidential. For more information on data privacy, refer to .

The tool creates a tar ball in the /var/log directory. Attach the log file tar ball to your service request or if you cannot, email it to the engineer. For more detailed information on working with SUSE Technical Support, see .

If problems occur, use the supportconfig command-line tool to collect and organize system information and logs. This helps reduce the time needed to resolve service requests. The collected data includes details such as the current kernel version, hardware, installed packages, partition setup and more, and is automatically attached to your service request.
The command-line tool is provided by the package supportutils, which is installed by default. If the package is not installed, install it with:

The supportconfig tool can integrate plug-ins that run automatically each time the command is executed. Which plug-ins are available on your system, depends on the installed packages. The plug-ins are stored in the /usr/lib/supportconfig/plugins/ directory.
The supportconfig tool creates a TAR archive with detailed system information that you can hand over to Global Technical Support.
To create a TAR archive with detailed system information that you can hand over to Global Technical Support, follow the procedure:

step.para: Run supportconfig as root. Usually, it is enough to run this tool without any options. For common options, refer to .
step.screen:
# supportconfig
Support Utilities - Supportconfig Script Version: 3.1.11-46.2 Library Version: 3.1.11-29.6 Script Date: 2022 10 18 [...] Gathering system information Data Directory: /var/log/scc_d251_180201_1525
Basic Server Health Check... Done RPM Database... Done Basic Environment... Done System Modules... Done [...] File System List... Skipped [...] Command History... Excluded [...] Supportconfig Plugins: 1 Plugin: pstree... Done [...] Creating Tar Ball
==[ DONE ]=================================================================== Log file tar ball: /var/log/scc_d251_180201_1525.txz Log file size: 732K Log file md5sum: bf23e0e15e9382c49f92cbce46000d8b =============================================================================/
step.para: The command output is described below this procedure.
Wait for the tool to complete the operation.
The default archive location is /var/log, with the file name format being scc_HOST_DATE_TIME.txz. For the archive content description, refer to .

callout.para: The temporary data directory to store the results. This directory is archived as a tar file, see .
The feature was skipped because certain files of one or more RPM packages were changed.
The feature was excluded because it was deselected via the -x option.
The script found one plug-in and executes the plug-in pstree. The plug-in was found in the directory /usr/lib/supportconfig/plugins/. See the man page for details.
The tar file name of the archive, compressed with xz by default.

section.para: Usually, it is sufficient to run supportconfig without any options. However, you may need to use the following options:

listitem.para: To provide the contact e-mail.
To provide your name.
To provide your company name.
To provide your phone number.
To specify keywords that limit the features to check. KEYWORDS is a comma-separated list of case-sensitive keywords.

This option is particularly useful if you have already localized a problem that relates to a specific area or feature set only. For example, you have detected problems with LVM and want to test a recent change that you introduced to the LVM configuration. In this case, it makes sense to gather the minimum supportconfig information around LVM only:
To list all keywords that you can use to limit the features to check.
To reduce the amount of the information being gathered.
To collect already rotated log files. This is especially useful in high-logging environments or after a kernel crash when syslog rotates the log files after a reboot.

section.para: Use supportconfig -helpcommand to get a list of all the options.

The TAR archive contains all the results from the features. Depending on what you have selected (all or only a small set), the archive can contain more or fewer files. The set of features can be limited using the -i option (see ).
To list the contents of an xz compressed tar file:
The following file names are always available inside the TAR archive:

listitem.para: Contains the date when this script was executed and system information like version of the distribution, hypervisor information, and more.
Contains basic health checks, such as uptime, virtual memory statistics, free memory and hard disk, checks for zombie processes, and more.
Contains basic hardware checks like information about the CPU architecture, a list of all connected devices, interrupts, I/O ports, kernel boot messages, and more.
Contains log messages from the system journal.
Contains a list of all installed RPM packages, their names and versions and where they come from.
Contains information in XML format, such as distribution, version and product-specific fragments.
Contains information about the supportconfig script itself.
Contains YaST-specific information like specific packages, configuration files and log files.

section.para: The following table lists some of the available features and their file names.

table.title: Comparison of features and file names in the TAR archive

info.title: Submitting information to Global Technical Support

section.para: After you have created the archive using the supportconfig tool, you can submit the archive to SUSE.

section.title: Creating a service request number
section.para: Before handing over the supportconfig data to Global Technical Support, you need to generate a service request number first. You will need it to upload the archive to support.
To create a service request, go to and follow the instructions on the screen. Write down the service request number.

note.title: Privacy statement
note.para: SUSE treats system reports as confidential data. For details about our privacy commitment, see .

section.title: Uploading targets
section.para: After having created a service request number, you can upload your supportconfig archives to Global Technical Support. In the examples below, 12345678901 serves as a placeholder for your service request number. Replace the placeholder with the service request number you created in .
The following procedures assume that you have already created a supportconfig archive but have not uploaded it yet.

procedure.title: Submitting information to support on servers with Internet connectivity

step.para: Run the supportconfig tool as follows:
To use the default upload target , run:
For the FTPS upload target , use the following command:

To use a different upload target, for example, for the EMEA area, use the -U followed by the particular URL, either
or :
After the TAR archive arrives in the incoming directory of our FTP server, it becomes automatically attached to your service request.

section.para: If the servers do not provide Internet connectivity, follow the steps below:

procedure.title: Submitting information to support on servers without Internet connectivity

step.para: Manually upload the /var/log/scc_SR12345678901*txz archive to one of our servers. The selection of a server depends on your location in the world:

listitem.para: North America: HTTPS , FTPS
EMEA, Europe, the Middle East, and Africa: FTP , FTPS

step.para: After the TAR archive arrives in the incoming directory of our FTP server, it becomes automatically attached to your service request.

section.para: The SUSE Technical Support Handbook provides detailed information on how to work with SUSE technical support. Below are links to key sections, but you may also find it helpful to review the full handbook.

para.link: Types of support and what is technical support
How to effectively work with support

appendix.para: If you have Invariant Sections, Front-Cover Texts and Back-Cover Texts, replace the “with...Texts.” line with this:
appendix.screen: with the Invariant Sections being LIST THEIR TITLES, with the Front-Cover Texts being LIST, and with the Back-Cover Texts being LIST.
appendix.para: If you have Invariant Sections without Cover Texts, or some other combination of the three, merge those two alternatives to suit the situation.
